questions.text: Most common congenital anomaly of larynx is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Laryngomalacia Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital anomaly of the larynx. It occurs due to softening of the tissues of the larynx, particularly the epiglottis, causing it to collapse inward during inspiration. This leads to stridor (a high-pitched sound) and respiratory distress, especially in the first few months of life. Laryngomalacia typically resolves on its own as the child grows and the tissues of the larynx become firmer. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Laryngeal web: A laryngeal web is a congenital condition where there is a membrane or web-like structure that can partially or completely obstruct the laryngeal airway. While it can cause airway obstruction and hoarseness, it is rarer than laryngomalacia and typically presents with severe respiratory distress depending on the degree of obstruction. B. Laryngeal stenosis: Laryngeal stenosis refers to a narrowing or constriction of the laryngeal airway, which can be congenital or acquired. It can lead to breathing difficulties, but it is less common than laryngomalacia and is often more severe, requiring intervention such as surgery or dilation. D. Laryngeal papilloma: Laryngeal papillomas are benign growths caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. They are not congenital but rather acquired later, often presenting in infants and young children due to vertical transmission of the virus. They are less common compared to laryngomalacia and do not present with the typical stridor seen in laryngomalacia.

questions.text: Chandu, a one-year old child with pneumonia should be admitted in hospital for the following complaints except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Explanation: Indications for hospital admission in childhood pneumonia (Ref. WHO update 2015, Nelson 20th Ed, PGI pediatric protocols by Singhi S et al) Inability to feed or drink Lethargy: Abnormally sleepy or difficult to awake Persistent vomiting and dehydration Convulsions or seizures Age below 1 year Central cyanosis Severe grunting Severe malnutrition Suspected complication of pneumonia

choices.text: Examine the throat and obtain a culture
Obtain ABG and start on IV line
Order a chest X-ray and lateral view of neck

questions.text: A 6-year old boy is brought to the emergency room with 3-hour history of fever to 100oF & sore throat. The child appears alert but anxious and toxic. He has mild inspiratory stridor and is drooling. You should immediately-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The child has features of acute epiglottitis. Immediately securing airway is paramount and should not be delayed pending investigations. After securing airway by intubation, we can start IV fluids, IV antibiotics and perform necessary investigations to confirm the diagnosis. According to Nelson 20th Ed, “Epiglottitis is a medical emergency and warrants immediate treatment with an artificial airway placed under controlled conditions, either in an operating room or intensive care unit.”

choices.text: Nasal washings of RSV and influenza virus

questions.text: A 2-year old boy came to emergency department at 3 am with dyspnoea and fever. It was associated with barking cough and stridor was present only on crying. But child was consolable and well hydrated and was able to drink. Next management is –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The child presents with barking cough, fever, stridor only on crying, and is consolable, well hydrated, and able to drink. These findings are consistent with mild croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis). According to Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, dexamethasone (oral, IM, or IV) is recommended for all severities of croup, including mild. It helps reduce airway inflammation and improve symptoms over time. Since the child does not have stridor at rest or respiratory distress, dexamethasone alone is sufficient. Why Option A is Incorrect (Nebulized epinephrine): Nebulized racemic epinephrine is indicated for moderate to severe croup, characterized by stridor at rest, increased work of breathing, or signs of hypoxia. It works by causing vasoconstriction and reducing laryngeal edema quickly. However, in this case, the child only has stridor when crying, with no distress at rest, so this would be an unnecessary escalation of treatment. Why Option C is Incorrect (Blood culture and blood exam): Routine blood investigations are not required in typical viral croup. There are no signs of sepsis or bacterial superinfection (like high-grade fever, toxicity, or persistent distress). Therefore, blood tests would not guide management and are not recommended at this stage. Why Option D is Incorrect (Nasal washings for RSV/influenza): Although viral testing can confirm the etiology (e.g., RSV, parainfluenza), it does not change immediate management. Croup is clinically diagnosed, and management is symptom-based. Hence, nasal washings are not routinely performed in the emergency setting for typical croup.

questions.text: A 3-year old boy is brought to the casualty by his mother with progressive shortness of breath for 1-day duration. The child has history of bronchial asthma. On examination the child is blue, gasping and unresponsive. What will you like to do first–
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Normally, any child presenting with acute severe asthma needs to be started on 100% oxygen followed by salbutamol nebulization. However, this child is blue, gasping and unresponsive (indicating almost complete airway obstruction with depressed consciousness). These children have high mortality and since respiratory efforts are poor (gasping), the child will not benefit from oxygen alone. We will immediately start bag and mask ventilation, followed by intubating the child to save the life of the child. Also remember: In any child with severe persistent asthma without above features, starting 100% O2 will be the first step in management.

questions.text: A 2-year old female child was brought to a PHC with a history of cough and fever for 4 days with inability to drink for last 12 hours. On examination, the child was having weight of 5 kg and RR of 45/min with fever. The child will be classified as suffering from which among the following as per latest WHO categorisation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Severe pneumonia with danger sign The correct classification for this child, according to the latest WHO categorization, is B. Severe pneumonia with danger sign. This classification is based on the following clinical findings: Cough and fever for 4 days: This indicates a respiratory illness likely to be pneumonia. Inability to drink for 12 hours: This is a danger sign as it suggests the child is not able to maintain adequate hydration, which is concerning for a more severe infection. Respiratory rate (RR) of 45/min: A respiratory rate over 40/min in a child under 5 years is considered a sign of pneumonia. The elevated RR, combined with other signs like inability to drink, makes this case qualify as severe pneumonia with danger signs. Weight of 5 kg: Although the weight is below average for a 2-year-old, it does not change the classification. The child's clinical signs of respiratory distress and inability to drink make it clear that this is a more severe case of pneumonia. Incorrect responses: A. Very severe pneumonia: This classification is for cases where the child has extreme symptoms such as unconsciousness, convulsions, or significant respiratory distress like grunting or severe chest in-drawing. The child’s symptoms do not meet this level of severity, so this is not the correct classification. C. Pneumonia: While the child has pneumonia, the presence of the danger sign (inability to drink) and the increased respiratory rate suggest a more severe condition. This would be classified as severe pneumonia with danger sign, not just pneumonia. D. No pneumonia: Given the history of cough, fever, and respiratory distress (e.g., elevated respiratory rate), it is clear that this child has pneumonia, and thus, this option is incorrect.

choices.text: Multinucleate giant cells in the bronchiolar wall

questions.text: All of the following are seen in the viral pneumonia except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Alveolar exudates are predominantly seen in bacterial pneumonias. Viral pneumonias have interstitial infiltrates, moderate grade fever and sometimes giant cells in the bronchiolar wall (esp in measles). RSV-associated pneumonia can have overlapping features with acute bronchiolitis.

questions.text: A newborn baby becomes cyanosed on closing its mouth which disappears on crying. The most probable diagnosis is –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Bilateral choanal atresia. In this condition, the baby has a blockage of the posterior nasal passage, which is congenital and causes difficulty with breathing. The baby typically exhibits cyanosis that worsens when the mouth is closed and improves when the baby cries. Crying causes the infant to open the mouth, allowing air to bypass the blocked nasal passages, temporarily alleviating the cyanosis. This pattern of cyanosis, relieved by crying, is characteristic of bilateral choanal atresia. Explanation of incorrect options: A. Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF): TEF is a condition where there is an abnormal connection between the trachea and esophagus. It typically presents with respiratory distress, choking, or vomiting after feeding, but the cyanosis observed in TEF is not relieved by crying. It would not present with the improvement seen in this case upon crying. B. GERD (Gastroesophageal reflux disease): GERD in neonates presents as vomiting or regurgitation and sometimes respiratory symptoms, but it does not typically cause cyanosis that is relieved by crying. The symptoms of GERD are not directly related to the airway obstruction seen in choanal atresia. C. Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in infants, caused by the collapse of the laryngeal structures during inspiration. It presents with noisy breathing (stridor), but not with cyanosis that improves when crying. The cyanosis in laryngomalacia typically occurs due to airway obstruction during inspiration, not relieved by crying.

questions.text: Raju, a one-year old child suffering from mild fever for 2 days associated with sneezing and running nose is brought with increasing respiratory distress. Two other family members had similar symptoms. On examination he has a respiratory rate of 45/minute, with nasal flaring, SCR, ICR and bilateral wheeze. The most likely diagnosis is –
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- A The child has features of respiratory distress with fever and bilateral wheeze. Any child below 2 yr with such illness is presumed to have acute bronchiolitis unless proven otherwise. Also remember: As per Nelson 20th Ed, “Acute bronchiolitis is predominantly a viral disease. RSV is responsible for more than 50% of cases. Other agents include parainfluenza, adenovirus, rhinovirus, and Mycoplasma. Emerging pathogens include human metapneumovirus and human bocavirus, which may be a primary cause of viral respiratory infection or occur as a coinfection with RSV.”

questions.text: A 2-year old child is labelled as having pneumonia according to WHO guidelines, if the child has respiratory rate greater than?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 40 per min. According to the latest WHO guidelines, a child aged 2 years with a respiratory rate greater than 40 breaths per minute is classified as having pneumonia. This is part of the criteria used to identify children with pneumonia based on their respiratory rate, and it indicates that the child is experiencing respiratory distress likely due to infection. Explanation of incorrect options: A. 30 per min: A respiratory rate greater than 30 breaths per minute is not classified as pneumonia in a 2-year-old child. While an elevated respiratory rate could suggest respiratory distress, it does not meet the threshold for pneumonia under the WHO guidelines. C. 50 per min: A respiratory rate of 50 breaths per minute exceeds the threshold for pneumonia classification, but the WHO guideline for pneumonia in a child aged 2 years is 40 per minute. A rate of 50 per minute could indicate severe pneumonia or another respiratory condition, but it does not represent the exact threshold for pneumonia diagnosis. D. 60 per min: A respiratory rate of 60 breaths per minute is considered a sign of severe pneumonia with danger signs in children, indicating a more severe respiratory condition requiring urgent medical intervention. It is above the threshold for pneumonia but reflects a more critical condition.

questions.text: Most common cause of empyema in a child aged 2 years is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Staphylococcus. Staphylococcus aureus, particularly Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), is the most common cause of empyema in children aged 2 years. It is often associated with more severe forms of pneumonia and is a significant pathogen responsible for empyema in pediatric patients. Empyema refers to the collection of pus in the pleural cavity, usually as a complication of bacterial pneumonia. Explanation of incorrect options: A. E. coli: Escherichia coli is less commonly associated with empyema in children. While it can cause pneumonia in some cases, it is not the most frequent cause of empyema in children. B. Pneumococcus: Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus) is a common cause of bacterial pneumonia in children, and it can lead to empyema. However, Staphylococcus aureus is generally more prevalent as the cause of empyema in this age group. C. Klebsiella: Klebsiella pneumoniae is another potential pathogen that can cause pneumonia and empyema in children, but it is less common compared to Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: A child aged 2 years with fever since 3 days and cough since one day has progressive respiratory distress and noisy breathing. X-ray neck appearance is shown below. What is the likely etiological agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Parainfluenza virus. The clinical presentation of fever, cough, progressive respiratory distress, and noisy breathing, combined with the X-ray appearance of a "steeple sign" (which suggests narrowing of the upper trachea), is characteristic of croup, which is commonly caused by the parainfluenza virus. Croup primarily affects children between 6 months and 3 years of age and is associated with inflammation of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi, causing the characteristic symptoms of barking cough, stridor, and hoarseness. The "steeple sign" is a classic radiologic finding in croup, indicating subglottic narrowing. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. Strep pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of bacterial pneumonia in children, and although it can cause respiratory distress, it does not typically present with the hallmark "steeple sign" on X-ray. Pneumococcal pneumonia is more likely to present with lobar consolidation rather than the airway obstruction seen in croup. B. Strep pyogenes: Streptococcus pyogenes is a bacterial pathogen that can cause throat infections like pharyngitis or tonsillitis and can also lead to complications like scarlet fever or rheumatic fever. However, it is not a common cause of the croup-like symptoms seen in this case, and it would not be associated with the "steeple sign" on X-ray. D. Hemophilus influenzae: Haemophilus influenzae is a bacterial pathogen that can cause respiratory infections such as epiglottitis, which can also lead to respiratory distress. However, epiglottitis typically presents with a "thumbprint sign" on X-ray (enlarged epiglottis), not the "steeple sign." Additionally, epiglottitis is more commonly seen in children aged 2-6 years and is less likely to cause the barking cough seen in croup.

questions.text: A child presented with recurrent sinusitis, situs inversus and dextrocardia. Likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Kartagener syndrome. Kartagener syndrome is a subtype of primary ciliary dyskinesia characterized by the classic triad of recurrent sinusitis, situs inversus (a condition where the organs are mirrored from their normal positions), and dextrocardia (where the heart is located on the right side of the chest instead of the left). This syndrome occurs due to defects in the ciliary structure or function, leading to impaired mucociliary clearance, which predisposes the child to recurrent respiratory infections such as sinusitis and bronchitis. Situs inversus and dextrocardia are often seen due to the abnormal development of the cilia during embryogenesis. Explanation of incorrect responses: B. William-Campbell syndrome: William-Campbell syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by malformation of the cartilage in the trachea and bronchi, leading to tracheomalacia. It is not associated with situs inversus or dextrocardia, and the recurrent sinusitis seen in Kartagener syndrome is not a hallmark of this condition. C. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome: Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a group of connective tissue disorders characterized by hypermobility of joints, skin hyperelasticity, and tissue fragility. While this syndrome can affect multiple organ systems, it does not present with the characteristic features of recurrent sinusitis, situs inversus, and dextrocardia seen in Kartagener syndrome. D. Marfan syndrome: Marfan syndrome is a connective tissue disorder primarily affecting the cardiovascular, skeletal, and ocular systems. It is characterized by long limbs, tall stature, and cardiovascular problems such as aortic aneurysms, but it does not involve recurrent sinusitis, situs inversus, or dextrocardia.

questions.text: A 7 year old child presented with non-productive cough and dyspnea. After giving oral antibiotics, there was initial mild improvement, followed by increasing respiratory distress, mild fever and bilateral wheeze. Chest X-ray showed hyperlucency and PFT showed obstructive pattern. Most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bronchiolitis obliterans (BO), a chronic obstructive lung disease of the bronchioles and smaller airways, results from an insult to the lower respiratory tract leading to fibrosis of the small airways. In the nontransplant patient, BO most commonly occurs in the pediatric population after respiratory infections, particularly adenovirus. Cough, fever, cyanosis, dyspnea, chest pain, and respiratory distress followed by initial improvement may be the initial signs of BO. Chest radiographs may be relatively normal compared with the extent of physical findings but can demonstrate hyperlucency and patchy infiltrates. PFT shows obstructive pattern. Exercise testing shows reduced exercise capacity andimpaired oxygen consumption. Ventilation–perfusion scans reveal a typical moth-eaten appearance of multiple matched defects in ventilation and perfusion. High-resolution chest CT often demonstrates patchy areas or a mosaic pattern of hyperlucency, air trapping, and bronchiectasis. No definitive therapy exists for BO. Administration of corticosteroids may be beneficial.

questions.text: Most common cause of pneumonia in cystic fibrosis in a 3 year old child is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Staphylococcus aureus. In children with cystic fibrosis, Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of pneumonia, particularly in the early years of life. This bacterium can cause both upper and lower respiratory tract infections in children with cystic fibrosis, and it is a common pathogen during the first few years of life. Staphylococcus aureus is known to be a significant pathogen in cystic fibrosis patients, and it can cause acute respiratory exacerbations, leading to pneumonia and other respiratory complications. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Although Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major pathogen in cystic fibrosis, it typically becomes more prevalent in older children, often after 3-4 years of age. It is a common cause of chronic lung infections and exacerbations in cystic fibrosis patients. However, Staphylococcus aureus is generally the more common pathogen in young children with cystic fibrosis. B. Mycoplasma pneumoniae: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of pneumonia in children without cystic fibrosis. However, it is not the most common pathogen in cystic fibrosis, where bacterial infections like Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa are more predominant. C. Burkholderia cepacia: Burkholderia cepacia is another pathogen that can cause lung infections in cystic fibrosis patients, but it is less common than Staphylococcus aureus and typically seen in more advanced cases of cystic fibrosis, particularly in children who have had prolonged illness or multiple hospitalizations.

questions.text: For a child with aspirated foreign body, treatment of choice is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rigid bronchoscopy. In cases of foreign body aspiration, rigid bronchoscopy is the treatment of choice. It allows for direct visualization of the airway and provides a more effective means of removing the foreign body from the trachea or bronchi. The rigid bronchoscope offers better control over the airway and suction, and its design allows for the removal of larger or more difficult foreign bodies compared to a flexible bronchoscope. It is considered the gold standard procedure for the management of foreign body aspiration in children, especially in emergency situations. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. Chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can be useful in diagnosing foreign body aspiration, it is not a treatment method. It may show signs such as air trapping, atelectasis, or the presence of the foreign body, but it does not treat the aspiration itself. The X-ray is primarily used for diagnostic purposes, not therapeutic intervention. C. Flexible bronchoscopy: Flexible bronchoscopy is another option for removing foreign bodies from the airway, but it is typically used in less urgent cases or in adults. It is less effective than rigid bronchoscopy for foreign body removal, especially in young children or when the foreign body is large or difficult to access. D. Direct laryngoscopy: Direct laryngoscopy is not the preferred treatment for foreign body aspiration. It is primarily used for examining the larynx and vocal cords. While it can help in some cases of upper airway obstruction, it is not typically used for lower airway foreign body removal, which is where rigid bronchoscopy comes in.

questions.text: The most important cause of under 5 mortality rate is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Respiratory infections. Respiratory infections, including pneumonia, are the leading cause of under-5 mortality worldwide. Pneumonia accounts for a significant proportion of child deaths, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. The vulnerability of young children to respiratory infections is compounded by factors such as malnutrition, inadequate access to healthcare, and poor sanitation. Early diagnosis and appropriate treatment, such as antibiotics, are crucial in reducing mortality due to respiratory infections. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. Diarrhea: Diarrhea remains a major cause of under-5 mortality, especially in developing countries. However, it ranks lower than respiratory infections in terms of the number of deaths. Improved access to clean water, sanitation, and oral rehydration therapy has significantly reduced mortality from diarrheal diseases in recent decades. B. Malnutrition: Malnutrition contributes to under-5 mortality as it weakens the immune system, making children more susceptible to infections, including respiratory infections and diarrhea. While it is a significant underlying cause of death, it is not the most direct cause compared to respiratory infections. D. Trauma: Trauma (such as accidents, burns, and injuries) does contribute to under-5 mortality but accounts for a much smaller proportion of deaths compared to respiratory infections, diarrhea, and malnutrition.

choices.text: Connect pulse oximeter & perform ABG if needed.

questions.text: Kumar 1½ year old child accidentally drinks kerosene mistaking it for water. After 6 hours he developed cough,tachypnea and retractions. In the emergency department, the first step in management is –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Connect pulse oximeter & perform ABG if needed. In the case of a child who has ingested kerosene, the first step in management is to assess the child’s respiratory status. Since kerosene ingestion can lead to aspiration and chemical pneumonitis, monitoring oxygen saturation and assessing the child’s respiratory status are critical. Pulse oximetry will help evaluate oxygenation, and an arterial blood gas (ABG) may be needed if the child shows signs of respiratory distress or hypoxia, as suggested by the development of cough, tachypnea, and retractions. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. Stimulate vomiting: Inducing vomiting is generally not recommended in cases of kerosene ingestion. Vomiting can increase the risk of aspiration of the kerosene, which can worsen the child's respiratory distress. Ingested hydrocarbons like kerosene are highly irritative to the lungs and may cause aspiration pneumonitis if vomited. B. Give charcoal: Activated charcoal is used in some poisoning cases to absorb toxins from the gastrointestinal tract, but it is not effective in cases of kerosene ingestion. Kerosene is a hydrocarbon and does not bind to charcoal. Additionally, giving charcoal can increase the risk of aspiration in a child who may already be struggling with respiratory issues. C. Do nasogastric lavage: Nasogastric lavage is not routinely recommended in cases of kerosene ingestion. Similar to the use of activated charcoal, gastric lavage is ineffective in hydrocarbon poisoning and may cause further complications, such as aspiration pneumonia.

questions.text: A previously healthy active 18-month old presents with unilateral nasal obstruction & foul-smelling discharge. The examination is otherwise unremarkable. The most likely diagnosis is –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Unilateral nasal obstruction with foul-smelling discharge is the classic presentation of retained foreign body in the nose in young children. According to Nelson 20th Ed, “Unilateral nasal discharge and obstruction should suggest the presence of a foreign body, which can often be seen on examination with a nasal speculum or wide otoscope placed in the nose.”

questions.text: Staccato paroxysms of cough are seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chlamydia infection. Staccato paroxysms of cough, characterized by rapid, sharp bursts of coughing followed by a brief pause, are commonly seen in Chlamydia trachomatis infection. This type of cough is most often observed in neonates and young infants who have acquired chlamydial pneumonia through vertical transmission (from mother to baby during delivery). The cough may be persistent and is often associated with other respiratory symptoms like wheezing and tachypnea. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. Allergic cough sinusitis: Allergic cough and sinusitis can cause coughing, but it is usually more persistent and not characterized by staccato paroxysms. Allergic cough tends to be associated with other signs of allergy, like sneezing, watery eyes, and nasal congestion, rather than the sharp, intermittent coughing seen in chlamydial infection. B. Tracheitis: Tracheitis is an infection of the trachea that can lead to a cough, but it usually presents with a barky or stridor-like cough due to the inflammation of the airway. The cough is not typically described as staccato. C. Psychogenic cough: Psychogenic cough is typically a habitual or non-productive cough that is often associated with emotional stress or anxiety. It may be intermittent and can last for hours or days, but it does not present as the distinct staccato paroxysms seen in chlamydial infection.

choices.text: IV antibiotics at PHC and observe
Give first dose antibiotic and refer to higher center
Oral antibiotics for 5 days and send home

questions.text: An 18 month old child comes to a subcentre with fever and cough. On examination, weight was 11.5 kg, respiratory rate was 46/min and no chest indrawing. Most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Oral antibiotics for 5 days and send home. The child in this scenario has fever, cough, and an increased respiratory rate (46/min), but does not have signs of severe pneumonia such as chest indrawing or danger signs like hypoxia or cyanosis. According to the latest WHO guidelines for pneumonia management, a child with mild to moderate pneumonia and no severe symptoms can be treated with oral antibiotics (such as amoxicillin) for 5 days. Since this child does not meet criteria for severe pneumonia, they can be safely sent home with oral antibiotics. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. IV antibiotics at PHC and observe: IV antibiotics and observation would be reserved for cases of severe pneumonia or those with danger signs. This child does not show evidence of severe pneumonia, such as chest indrawing, difficulty breathing, or signs of systemic illness (e.g., lethargy or vomiting), so IV antibiotics are not indicated. B. Give first dose antibiotic and refer to higher center: Referral to a higher center would be necessary if the child had more severe symptoms, such as respiratory distress, hypoxia, or inability to feed. Since this child has no severe signs, referral is unnecessary, and the management should be done locally. D. Home based local remedies: Local remedies are not recommended for pneumonia, as antibiotics are required to treat the underlying bacterial infection. The child needs a proper antibiotic course to manage pneumonia effectively.

questions.text: Loeffler’s syndrome is characterised by?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Loeffler syndrome is characterized by transient, migrating lung infiltrates and by eosinophilia in the peripheral blood. It occurs in sensitized hosts during the stage of larval migration through the lungs. This syndrome can be a response to several parasitic infestations, ascariasis being the commonest aetiology.

questions.text: Most common cause of ARDS in children is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Severe pneumonia with sepsis. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) in children is most commonly caused by severe pneumonia with sepsis. This condition can lead to widespread lung inflammation, impaired gas exchange, and respiratory failure. Pneumonia, especially when complicated by sepsis, is a leading cause of ARDS in pediatric patients. The body's inflammatory response to infection leads to damage of the alveolar-capillary membrane, resulting in pulmonary edema and hypoxemia. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. Aspiration: While aspiration of foreign material (such as food, liquid, or vomit) can lead to a form of respiratory distress, it is less common than pneumonia as a cause of ARDS in children. Aspiration pneumonia can cause inflammation and damage to the lungs but is not as frequent as pneumonia with sepsis in causing ARDS. B. Injury: Trauma or physical injury (e.g., chest trauma, near drowning) can lead to ARDS, but this is less common in children compared to severe pneumonia with sepsis. Injury-related ARDS often results from the direct effect of the injury on lung tissue or a secondary inflammatory response. D. DIC (Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation): DIC is a complication that can result from conditions such as severe infection or trauma. While DIC can contribute to lung injury and ARDS, it is not the most common cause of ARDS in children. It is typically a consequence of other underlying conditions, such as severe infection or trauma, rather than an independent cause of ARDS.

questions.text: Pneumatoceles are produced by infection in children by which organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Staphylococcus aureus. Pneumatoceles are air-filled cystic lesions that can form in the lungs as a result of infection. In children, Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism associated with the development of pneumatocele, particularly in the context of community-acquired pneumonia or severe infections such as necrotizing pneumonia. The infection leads to localized lung tissue damage, causing the formation of these air-filled cavities. Explanation of incorrect responses: B. Pseudomonas: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is known to cause severe lung infections, particularly in immunocompromised patients or those with cystic fibrosis, but it is less commonly associated with the formation of pneumatocele compared to Staphylococcus aureus. C. Strep pyogenes: While Streptococcus pyogenes can cause severe infections like necrotizing fasciitis or pneumonia, it is not typically associated with the formation of pneumatocele. Pneumatoceles are more often linked with Staphylococcus aureus infections. D. Hemophilus influenzae: Haemophilus influenzae can cause pneumonia and other respiratory infections, especially in children, but it is not a common cause of pneumatocele formation. Pneumatoceles are more frequently associated with Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: The commonest cause of Bacterial pneumonia in children is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Streptococcus pneumoniae. Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia in children. It can cause both community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and severe pneumonia in children, especially those under 5 years of age. Pneumococcal pneumonia is often characterized by fever, cough, difficulty breathing, and chest pain. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. Streptococcus pyogenes: While Streptococcus pyogenes can cause respiratory infections, including pharyngitis and occasionally pneumonia, it is not the most common bacterial cause of pneumonia in children. It is more commonly associated with other types of infections, such as skin infections, scarlet fever, and pharyngitis. B. Haemophilus influenzae: Haemophilus influenzae (especially type B) was historically a common cause of pneumonia in children, particularly before the introduction of the Hib vaccine. However, with widespread vaccination, the incidence of Haemophilus influenzae-related pneumonia has decreased significantly, making Streptococcus pneumoniae the leading cause. D. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus can also cause bacterial pneumonia, particularly in severe or complicated cases, such as in children with underlying conditions or following viral infections. It is not, however, the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia in the general pediatric population.

questions.text: A CHILD WITH DIAPHRAGMATIC HERNIA, WHAT IS NOT TO BE DONE?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Bag & Mask ventilation is contraindicated in diaphragmatic hernia as air will go via oesophagus and distend the stomach,which will further compress the lungs,resulting in worsening. Option B,C,D-Intubation ,tracheostomy and PPV leads to entry of air into lungs,hence they can be done in case of diaphragmatic hernia.
